issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: This issue is undergoing QA.  See linked QA issue(s) for progress.
status.name: In QA

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
When the NC and CC are not receiving messages from their upstream components but are started they do not log anything. We should have a message like:

I AM WAITING FOR A CC TO TALK TO ME
fields.summary: CC and NC need to log *something* when they start

comments.body:
So - the right way to do this is to switch on the axis2c service initialization call, which will require that the build be modified to patch the ADB service initialization to make a call to a CC/NC function that just does initialization.  We actually have such a function already written in the CC (doInitCC), but havn't done the patch work in the build process to enable it.  I tested manually and it appears to work. 

The question is one of timing - it is a bit of a different process lifecycle to have the CC/NC start up and begin doing their thing right away (as opposed to starting up upon first receiving a message from the CLC which is how it has been up until now), so I hesitate to make such a change at this point in time.  

If this is an urgent issue (or if others are confident in the change - in particular NC folks), then I think we should go ahead and enable 'auto-startup' in the CC/NC using this method - otherwise, I would like to make this change for future versions where more testing can be done.  

RFC!

-D

[~nurmi],

I don't know how critical this is and agree with you that this changes how we do things and considering that today we can probably look at the axis logs and http_error logs to find out if process has been started for troubleshooting. But if we do anything, better now than 3 weeks from now ;)
I don't have the cycles to make the change. But I don't mind if someone else does.

[~nurmi], [~dmitrii],

I have the cycles for doing the code on the NC (I think [~nurmi] has it done but not hooked for the CC). Just need confirmation that we want this now...

Talked to Chuck, talked to Vic - decision is to enable the CC/NC initialization routines post 4.0 (4.0.1).

_D
a note to add to the preliminary checks to look for existence of the *-client.xml files in var/lib/eucalyptus/keys

I'd lie to split this into different issues 

- this one (CC/NC start logging as soon as they start)

and

- do some init checks on startup

the reason is that, currently, some checks are done by init scripts, the NC does some using a small client program, etc.  this should be unified using one mechanism if possible

-D

in maint/4.0/testing:

commit 42032987e8c15102e16cf2beb47f2513c4b3fa79
Author: Daniel Nurmi <nurmi@eucalyptus.com>
Date:   Mon Jun 16 15:45:29 2014 -0700

    fix for EUCA-8901: CC and NC now start right away instead of waiting for a m
essage after registration

NOTE: this is a change that has pending for a long time - CC and NC processes now start *immediately* after the process is started from the init script - in other words, they will now run before they have credentials or receive a message from their parent component.  

There are no known issues with this change, but there may be unintended side effects from this process lifecycle alteration (this is a note to be aware of the change, not about any particular known issue with the change)

Fix Verified.

Installed Packages
Name        : eucalyptus
Arch        : x86_64
Version     : 4.0.1
Release     : 0.0.22217.19.20140711git3feddfa.el6

Tested 2 scenarios:

Scenario 1
# Running system, stopped all components. Set a merker in cc.log and nc.log
# started nc - noted nc.log being written to
# started cc - noted cc.log being written to

Scenario 2
# fresh centos install
# installed CC and NC 
# started NC - noticed nc.log was created and has messages including "component started"
# started CC - noticed cc.log was created and has messages including "component started"

output from new install (yeah there was no config done so there are messages in the logs about that)
